citations.narrative:
The facility has not conducted annual reviews of their contingency plan. The facility representative stated they were
unsure if annual reviews had been completed, recommending the inspector follow-up with the licensee to verify. Upon
speaking with the licensee, they confirmed annual reviews have not been completed by the facility.
Reviewing the outlined plan in place ensures the facility has assessed the current plan for any needed amendments to
better prepare for unexpected disasters or events, as well as a detailed strategy to address instructions for, but not limited
to: animal evacuation, sheltering-in-place, and backup provisions for husbandry and food/watering supplies, sanitation,
and ventilation. The facility shall develop and document an appropriate contingency plan available for review upon USDA
inspections.
Correct by June 14, 2024.

The food receptacle used for the camel had caked debris and buildup inside the bottom of container. The facility
representative thought the caked material was due to the medicine added to the feed for the camel. When the inspector
followed-up with the licensee, they stated the hardened residue present was likely due to the camel salivating when
consuming its feed. When asked when the food receptacle was last cleaned, the licensee stated the food receptacle had
not been cleaned for roughly a month.
Failure to appropriately clean food receptacles promotes unsanitary surfaces that can harm the animals’ health upon
ingestion, as well as attract unwanted pests and insects. Food receptacles shall be kept clean and sanitary at all times. If
self-feeders are used, adequate measures shall be taken to prevent molding, contamination, and deterioration or caking
of food.
Correct by June 5, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative and licensee.
